The Chlorine/Sulfur Dioxide Systems of WWTP is subject to comply with EPA Prevention Program 3.  This is based on the worst case release scenario analysis results from both the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide Systems being subject to OSHA's PSM rule, 29 CFR 1910.119 and  EPA's RMP 40-CFR-68.  The City of Frederick accidental releaseprevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices, and it is in compliance with all applicable EPA and OSHA Prevention Program requirements.  This section describes the EPA and OSHA requirements the City has fulfilled as operator of our Frederick WWTP. The plan also includes the prevention steps taken beyond this regulatory requirement.  The City of Frederick?s WWTP?s Document Management System (DMS) contains in it the key OSHA/EPA document which details the operation of the prevention program.

The City of Frederick accidental release prevention program is based on OSHA PSM program and EPA RMP Level 3 prevention program (described above in section 1.1.2).  The plant has an emergency response program, which is coordinated (reviewed by) with the City of Frederick Fire Department, which is a member of Local Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC) along with Fort Detrick's HazMat Team.  This program includes an emergency response decision tree and a notification plan.  Emergency response drills and drill evaluations are conducted annually by the operating department.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed at that time.  To ensure the public's safety evacuation may be required during a major release.  Evacuation will begin with a minimum of 1.3 mile radius from the source.  The incident commander is advised to evacuate up to 4 miles radius based on the circumstances of the catastrophic release.  This is three times the distance recommended by the EPA Guidance.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the City of Frederick plant by the following:

High level of involvement in every aspect of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide system operations including participation in : 

    Safety committee 

        Chlorine PSM/RMP safety teams, 

    Development of the operation procedures, 

    Hazard evaluations,

    Process Hazards Analysis, and

    on-going training of the operators and other involved staff.

Preventive maintenance and mechanical integrity programs ensure the safe operation of the equipment and systems.

Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment that meets and/or  exceeds industry and regulatory standards.

Use of accurate and effective operating procedures written with the participation of the operators.  These documents are all controlled by City of Frederick WWTP document control system.

Management of all changes to the procedures, equipment and chemicals used by the City of Frederick on the site.  Again, the document control system is key to the high quality of the operation and its products.

Performance of a hazard review of equipment, plant, and procedures

Implementation of an audit and inspection program.

Chemical-specific prevention features of the plant include:  1).  the chlorine/sulfur dioxide building ventilation systems, 2).  chlorine and sulfur dioxide detectors and alarm system, 3).  Use of full face chlorine SCBA respirator worn by the operators during connection and disconnection of either the chlorine or sulfur dioxide ton containers, 4).  The availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) in the event of a HHC leak, 5).  employee training in operations and maintenance with emphasis on awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, 6).  Participation of the Frederick-Risk Coordinator and Fire department in site safety evaluations.

The City of Frederick has in use: policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  The program addresses each of  the EPA Program level 3 listed 12 elements, plus  RMP elements and OSHA rules needed to implement the program, and similar elements in place in the plant's OSHA PSM program.  These are maintained in the City of Frederick WWTP document control system under the Key Document listed below:

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CITY OF FREDERICK WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM RE-SUBMITTAL

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY EXCERPT 



68.155   Executive summary

The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements: 

(a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source; 

(b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled; 

(c) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; 

(d) The five-year accident history; 

(e) The emergency response program; and 

(f) Planned changes to improve safety. 



1.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY INTRODUCTION 68.155                                                                        

City of Frederick Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) operates a municipal wastewater treatment system at their plant.  The location is 100 Treatment Plant Road, Frederick, Maryland.  The location of one of the chemical storage and off- loading operations within the plant is Lat 39.425278, Long -077.379722, and our EPA ID number is1000 0012 0068.   This plant is the only City of Frederick WWTP.  The City has several water treatment plants.  This WWTP, as well as two water treatment plants have quantities of numerous regulated hazardous chemicals, above the EPA threshold that make them subject to Risk Management Program (RMP).  Only the WWTP RMP is covered in this submittal.  The WWTP has a unified Risk Management Program which also includes the elements of the OSHA Process Safety Management Program (PSM).

1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES     (A)

The City of Frederick WWTP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, equipment, procedures and management practices.  The plant prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68 Prevention Progr

am under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.  The Plant is also subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management Program, (PSM) 29 CFR-1910-119, of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.  The OSHA program is similar to the RMP Level 3Prevention Program and EPA Emergency Response Program.

1.2.    PREDICTIVE FILING (A) (1)

The plant does not need or claim predictive filing.  

1.3.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS (A) (1)

The City of Frederick WWTP has a management system in place.  The RMP responsible position is held by the Deputy Director of the DPW Operations.  The City of Frederick WWTP Superintendent oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP as well as the like PSM elements.  This program, along with other plant-wide and plant-specific policies, eliminates and/or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the plants RMP Process Safety Information and a copy is attached to this RMP*eSubmital.

1.4.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3 (A) (2)

The City of Frederick WWTP maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  The program addresses each of the EPA Program Level 3-listed 12 elements, and, RMP elements needed to implement the program, and the like elements in place in the plants' OSHA PSM program.  These are maintained by the WWTP Document Management System (DMS).  Besides the specific RMP/PSM polices, the plan has many supporting environmental, health and safety policies and procedures that augment the RMP/PSM program.  Also, the City of Frederick has many City-wide policies and procedures that the WWTP follows. 

1.5.    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT THE CITY OF FREDERICK WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT

The City of Frederick WWTP employs 26 full-time operators, maintenance and lab staff.  Two RMP and PSM chemicals that exceed the regulatory threshold are received, st

ored, and used in the treatment of the wastewater.  There is elemental chlorine in one-ton containers as well as sulfur dioxide also stored in one- ton containers.  The chlorine is used to disinfect the wastewater and the sulfur dioxide is used to react with excess chlorine before the water is discharged from the treatment process.

 1.6.    SITE DESCRIPTION (B) (1)    

The site is owned and operated by The City of Frederick and managed by its Department of Public Works.  The site is located at 100 Treatment Plant Road, Frederick, MD, just off of Gas House Pike.  The plant is boarded by  Gas House Pike to the north and north east, the City of Frederick Golf Course to the east, the Frederick Municipal Airport to the south and farm land to the west.

The Plant includes a separate highly hazardous chemical storage building that includes a control room as well as pump room.  The building is mounted over the chlorination contact chambers.

The boundaries of the highly hazardous chemical system subject to the RMP regulation include the ton chlorine and sulfur dioxide Chemical Storage Room, the Feed Control room that houses the chemical control and injection systems, and the Hydro Tank Room which has one injection point.  Chlorine is also fed to the head of each of the two contact chambers, and sulfur dioxide is fed to the inlet of the dechlorination contact chamber. These are detailed in the Block Flow as well as the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the plant's RMP Process Safety Information.

1.6.1.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE (b) (2)

Chlorine and sulfur dioxide are the only regulated substances on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds and 5,000 pounds respectively.  The WWTP highly hazardous chemical process was installed as part of the process of purifying wastewater generated by the public and is recycled for reuse as well as discharged into t

he Monocacy River.  The WWTP operates under permit from the State of Maryland Department of the Environment.  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide are received, stored and distributed to the WWTP wastewater process control systems. 

Chlorine is an EPA and OSHA-listed toxic chemical.  It is an irritant and it is corrosive.  It is a halogen with the formula Cl2.  It is a chlorinating or oxidizing agent that is not flammable.  It has a one ppm OSHA ceiling Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) and a NFPA health rating of four, severe; with immediate and delayed health hazards.  Chlorine is not a carcinogen.  The maximum inventory stored on site is eight each, one ton containers.  This equals 16,000 pounds.

Sulfur dioxide is also an EPA and OSHA-listed toxic chemical.  It is an irritant and also corrosive.  Its formula is SO2 and in combination with water forms sulfuric acid.  It reacts with chlorine to form a salt and is used to scavenge the excess chlorine in the wastewater process.  It has a five PPM OSHA PEL.  The NFPA health rating is a three.  The maximum inventory stored on site is six each one-ton containers.  This equals 12,000 pounds.

 



2.    HAZARD ASSESSMENT

A hazard assessment was performed to determine the effects a release would have on the public and environment. For both chlorine and sulfur dioxide, the distance to a set endpoint concentration of the gas would travel was determined.  In addition, an estimate of the population that could be affected by a release of highly hazardous chemicals was determined, and sensitive receptors such as nursing homes were identified.  The hazard assessment considers two release scenarios-a "worst case" and an "alternative case". 

Two offsite consequence analyses were conducted.  The first is a "worst case release".  The second is a more probable "alternative release scenario".  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that "the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a

gas over 10 minutes" due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined "more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario".

Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by a chlorine release before its concentration decreases to the "toxic endpoint."  The EPA- specified endpoint for highly hazardous chemical is 0.0087 mg/l which equals 3 ppm. The 3 ppm endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  The sulfur dioxide endpoint is 0.0078 mg/l which equals about 3 ppm.  These levels are defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the "maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action."  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined, "to estimate the population potentially affected."

2.1.    WORST CASE   (C) (1)

Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case scenario was performed using the EPA assumptions and EPA's RMP Comp Program.  Results demonstrate a distance to the toxic endpoint for both chlorine and sulfur dioxide of 1.3 miles containing 5.3 square miles of area assuming an urban topography without an enclosure.  The residential population that could potentially be affected by the release is one individual based on the U. S. Census 2010 demographic data.  This data is kept on site in our process safety information.  All receptors were listed per the 2000 census data.

2.2.    ALTERNATIVE CASE   (C) (2)

The alternative release scenario involves the failure of the regulator of the pressure system or the pipes and valves connected to one of the one-ton containers.  This failure was defined during the recent Process Hazards Analysis.  This failure is equal to creating

a 0.004 square inch hole in the pipe or even the container itself.  Modeling using the EPA/RMP Comp and EPA's guidance demonstrated the rate of highly hazardous chemical release is 14.8 lb. /minutes for a period of 30 minutes releasing a total of 444 pounds of chlorine.  The toxic endpoint distances determined is 0.10 miles and is in the process safety information.  The residential population that would be impacted by this release is zero and is recorded in the process safety information.  Receptors in this area were identified as the municipal golf course adjacent to the plant.



3.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (D)

The City of Frederick WWTP accidental release prevention program is based on OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM program has been in place and has been effectively used for many years.  It is part of the plant's operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall City of Frederick WWTP Division-wide program and the City of Frederick WWTP Treatment Plant site-specific program.  The second is the chlorine or sulfur dioxide specific actions within the site program.  This is coordinated with the Frederick County LEPC and the City of Frederick Fire/Rescue Department (including the Ft. Detrick Haz Mat Team).

3.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   (D) (1)

Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written programs is listed below:

The City of Frederick WWTP has detailed process safety information on each of its operations. 

The document maintenance system is integral to the management of change for all operations on site control.  

Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphas awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used. Refresher training is conducted annually.

Maint

enance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment. 

Incident investigations of accidents and near-miss incidents ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident. 

Employees participate in all aspects of the plant as listed below under emergency response. 

Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lock Out Tag Out Permits, 3) Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines. 

Contractors must meet The Plant of City of Frederick WWTP's high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  Additionally, City of Frederick WWTP demands training of contractors to our standards. 

3.2.    HIGHLY HAZARDOUS CHEMICAL SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (D) (2)

3.2.1.    Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide Specific Operating Safety Information

Chemical-specific prevention features of the plant include the policies and procedures listed above and those of the highly hazardous chemical specific program.  Specific procedures for the management of the highly hazardous chemical process

Completion of a Pre-Startup Safety Review prior to the startup of the modified highly hazardous chemical system.   

Specific emergency response procedures for each highly hazardous chemical release as outlined below under both operating procedures and in the emergency response procedures. See the Emergency Response Program book. 

Specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for highly hazardous chemical is conducted annually. 

Finally, the details of both facility and equipment design are key to the safe operations of the highly hazardous chemical system.

3.2.2.    Facility Design

The highly hazardous chemical storage area is housed in a closed building.  Its doors are closed and locked requiring an entry key.  The entire plant is surrounded by a security fence.  The plant and

support equipment of the highly hazardous chemical storage building, the control room, and hydro room meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices.  The storage, hydro and control building rooms are equipped with forced ventilation systems.  There is a separate area monitor for chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  One for each will be found inside the storage room and one each in the control room.  If a highly hazardous chemical is detected, the monitor alarms and shuts down the forced air ventilation system.  It also starts the building chemical vent system.  Both monitors alarm in their local area as well as in the WWTP Main Control Room. 

3.2.3.    Equipment Design

Both chlorine and sulfur dioxide have two types of pipe systems, high pressure and low (vacuum) pressure.  The high pressure chemical piping system is made of chemical compatible steel pipes, copper or other like compatible components.  There are also non-metallic compounds (not corroded by chlorine or sulfur dioxide) all are rated to 500 psig.  The maximum pressure of the highly hazardous chemical in the high pressure system is only 150 psig giving a 3-to-1 safety factor.  There are two sets of four each one-ton containers on each chlorine line.  A vacuum check regulator is mounted on the top (vapor) angle valve of each ton container.  This valve opens when a vacuum from the control system is applied to it.  Upon opening chlorine vapor flows from the ton container into the vacuum check regulator and enters the manifold that carries it to the control system.  One bank is in service and the other is on standby.  An automatic switch over system places the standby ton containers on line when the ones in service are empty.  The sulfur dioxide is piped similarly however it only has three each, one- ton containers per set.

The low pressure system operates under a vacuum pressure of 13 inches of mercury.  There is a pressure relief valve which vents if the pressure in the line reaches above

atmospheric pressure.  All the pipe, tubes, and equipment are also chlorine or sulfur dioxide chemical compatible.  The system is designed to 150 psig or complete vacuum giving it a large safety factor over its typical vacuum pressure.

The above systems meet Chlorine Institute and manufacture design specifications as well as good engineering practices.



4.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)

The plant has been chemical reportable and release free for the past five years.



5.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)

Emergency response procedures are contained in the Plant Emergency Response Policy that is coordinated with the Frederick County Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan).  The plan includes an emergency response "decision tree" and a notification plan.  The Plant also has site-specific emergency actions for small releases defined in the plant's operating procedures.  Emergency response drills are conducted annually by the operating department.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed annually.

The emergency response program (contingency plan) is coordinated (reviewed by) with the plant Safety Committee.  The Plant coordinates with local Frederick County Local Response Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Fort Detrick HazMat Team.  All are located in Frederick County, Maryland.  Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including: the Frederick Fire and Rescue, Frederick Police and local medical, institutions.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the of Frederick WWTP staff.

The City-Wide Emergency Reponses Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to highly hazardous chemical spills (releases).  The plan includes training of all chlorine and sulfur dioxide area operators and maintenance staff. The primary response team includes the county Haz Mat Teams.  All of these respond to any severe highly hazardous chemical leak situat

ions.  Response actions types include catastrophic, severe, and moderate leaks.  A chemical "B" Leak Repair Kit is maintained at near chemical storage area to aid in stopping leaks.  Public notification is facilitated through the County Police and Sheriff's Office, which has an automated emergency dialing message system for public notification.



6.    PERSONNEL (F) (1)

Personnel are the key resource of the City of Frederick WWTP's prevention program.  Plant employees make up the operators and emergency operations first responders.  The City of Frederick WWTP fosters a high level of involvement in every aspect of the highly hazardous chemical system operations including participation in:

?    Development of the operation procedures, 

?    Hazard evaluations and 

?    On-going training of the operators and other involved staff.

?    Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) work group

?    PSM/RMP safety teams, 



7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (G)

Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the Process Hazards Analysis conducted in June 2012 using the HazOp method.  Other recommended actions have recently been completed based on the 2007 PHA and 2010 compliance audits as directed by the RMP program to meet requirements and make the plant safer.  The 2012 PHA recommended actions have also been resolved as required.  The City of Frederick WWTP staff continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, the City of Frederick WWTP management team and process safety team are reviewing potential upgrades to the existing design of the highly hazardous chemical operations to make the system even safer to prevent a release and minimize consequences in the event of a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide.
